title: How to Pack a Healthy and Safe Lunch

steps.headline: Rinse produce.
steps.description: Clean all fruits and vegetables before eating. Wash them under running water and dry them with a clean towel.

steps.headline: Keep hot foods hot by storing them in the correct container.
steps.description: Keep hot foods such as soup, chili or stew hot - 140 °F (60 °C) or above - by using an insulated container. Preheat the thermos with hot water and let stand. Drain the hot water and fill with hot food.

steps.headline: Keep cold foods cold by using appropriate storage containers.
steps.description: Use an insulated lunch bag. Metal or plastic lunch boxes and paper bags can also be used. Double sack paper lunch bags to increase their insulation qualities.

steps.headline: Use a frozen gel pack.
steps.description: Harmful bacteria multiply rapidly between the temperatures of 40 degrees and 140 °F (60 °C).

steps.headline: Freeze a juice pack to help keep the lunch cold.
steps.description: Use a frozen juice pack to keep things cold. Also, freeze sandwiches to help keep them chilled until lunchtime. The sandwiches will be thawed in time for lunch.

steps.headline: Put school lunches in the school refrigerator.
steps.description: If a refrigerator is available at school, that's the best option to keep food cold.

steps.headline: Keep lunch boxes away from direct sunlight and heat sources such as radiators and baseboards.
Throw out uneaten food.
steps.description: Toss what's left of lunch rather than saving the food for another lunch.

steps.headline: Keep shelf-stable foods handy.
steps.description: Consider keeping a supply of shelf-stable foods on hand for easy packing. These include crackers, nuts, dried fruit, peanut butter, packaged pudding and canned fruits or meats.

steps.headline: Prepare the lunch the night before.
steps.description: Making up the lunch the night before can be a real time saver. Sandwiches should be kept in the refrigerator, or frozen,  until time to go in the morning.

steps.headline: To save time consider making sandwiches in bulk.
steps.description: Line up the ingredients assembly line style and make a bunch of sandwiches in bulk. This is much like Once-a-Month cooking where foods are all prepared at once for later use. Freeze the sandwiches for later use. [[Image:Pack a Healthy and Safe Lunch Step 12.jpg}}
